Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Mechanisms of selectivity to behaviorally relevant sounds in the auditory midbrain
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many animals communicate with members of their own species using specific sounds. These vocalizations are behaviorally relevant to the animals because they facilitate important behaviors such as mating, maintaining a territory, or finding offspring on return from foraging. When an animal hears one of these behaviorally relevant sounds, it must make an appropriate response based on the information in the sound. To do this, the animal's auditory system must detect, discriminate, and categorize each of the sounds.

The goal of this project is to understand how neurons in the auditory midbrain achieve these tasks. The inferior colliculus is the first site in the ascending auditory system where individual neurons respond selectively to vocalizations but the mechanisms by which they do this are not well understood. Previously recorded vocalizations that were emitted by male mice when they were interacting with females will be presented as stimuli to female mice. Responses of individual neurons in the inferior colliculus will be recorded before and after pharmacological inactivation of inhibitory receptors to test the role of inhibition in shaping responses to vocalizations.

The importance of this research is in understanding the ways in which the brain has evolved to optimally respond to behaviorally relevant signals. This research will increase the understanding of how sound perception helps animals survive. A variety of broader impacts will result from this project, including training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. These students will be trained in neurophysiological techniques and will learn quantitative techniques through the groups active collaborations with mathematicians. This group of collaborators will develop and assess a neuroscience curriculum for middle school students, including units on acoustic communication, the auditory system and hearing loss. Included in this curriculum will be the development and assessment of alternative media methods, such as comics and graphic novels, for teaching about neuroscience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many animals use complex sounds to communicate information important for social behavior. The goals of this project were to better understand the neural processes that underlie the ability of animals to process different types of communication sounds. Because mice use a complex repertoire of vocalizations to communicate, we examined how neurons in the auditory system of mice process these different types of sounds. We recorded responses of individual neurons in awake mice and found that neurons at the level of the midbrain can discriminate among different vocalizations. This ability was previously thought to occur only a higher processing levels (like the primary auditory cortex). We also found that the complex interplay between excitatory and inhibitory projections to neurons in the auditory midbrain creates this ability to discriminate among different vocalizations. By blocking inhibitory projections pharmacologically, we found that inhibition plays a significant role in creating neural selectivity to particular vocalizations.

As these mouse vocalizations are extremely high frequency (up to 100 kHz), we also examined how they are produced. We used a novel high speed camera to observe the motion of the larygeal tissue outside the animal. We were able to reproduce natural looking mouse vocalizations.  We discovered that mice use a whistle mechanism to produce these high frequency vocalizations rather than a laryngeal vibration that is used by most other animals to produce vocalizations. This is significant for understanding the evolution of communication systems. This result was of much interest to the general public and was the highlighted in various newspaper articles, online forums, and radio shows. We disseminated our research findings to a variety of groups. We gave a number of "science pub" talks and created inquiry based learning experiences for elementary and middle school children. As two members of my lab are hispanic, they served as excellent role models to support the engagement of students from underrepresented groups in science.
